trans-unit.source: Specifies that a control can be in a certain state and that a <xref href="System.Windows.VisualState"></xref> is expected in the control's <xref href="System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate"></xref>.

Control authors use this attribute to specify the <xref:System.Windows.VisualState> and <xref:System.Windows.VisualStateGroup> objects that belong in their control's <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>.
For example, suppose that you create a new control that has two visual states named `Focused` and `Unfocused`, both of which are in a <xref:System.Windows.VisualStateGroup> named `FocusStates`.
To specify to <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate> authors that they can use those visual states, add two TemplateVisualStateAttribute attributes to the class signature of the control.

Specify that the <xref:System.Windows.TemplateVisualStateAttribute.GroupName%2A> property is `FocusStates` and that the <xref:System.Windows.TemplateVisualStateAttribute.Name%2A> property is `Focused` for one and `Unfocused` for the other.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.TemplateVisualStateAttribute"></xref> class.
Gets or sets the name of the group that the state belongs to.
The GroupName property corresponds to the <xref:System.Windows.VisualStateGroup.Name%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property of a <xref:System.Windows.VisualStateGroup> object.
To specify what <xref:System.Windows.VisualStateGroup> a <xref:System.Windows.VisualState> belongs in, set the GroupName property.
The name of the <xref href="System.Windows.VisualStateGroup"></xref> that the state belongs to.
Gets or sets the name of the state that the control can be in.
The Name property corresponds to the <xref:System.Windows.VisualState.Name%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property of a <xref:System.Windows.VisualState>.
To specify what <xref:System.Windows.VisualState> belongs in a control's <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ControlTemplate>, set the Name property.
The name of the state that the control can be in.
